campaign.story:
Epic wraparound cover by Fabio Ramacci and Ilaria Chiocca. (Trade dress not final)
Welcome, soldier! Your mission, should you choose to accept it: 
Fund PBOW: WORLD WAR BITCH No. 2,  a 40-page, saddle-stitch comic reuniting the creative team behind RED XMAS from Scout Comics. Readers call it...
Epic wraparound cover by Fabio Ramacci and Ilaria Chiocca
PBOW (that's Pregnant Bitches of War) launched in 2013 and quickly became a cult hit, selling through our website, comiXology, and Amazon. A crazy mix of over-the-top horror, sci-fi, grindhouse, and dark humor, it was a roller-coaster ride exploring a dark future where six pregnant women squared off against... well, Dad. 
Here's the pitch:
"Plucked from the time-stream by mad scientist Nikola Tesla, six pregnant women accidentally kill a young Hitler -- and unleash a nightmare future! Now, hunted by the Exalted Father, and with Tesla acting as Charlie to their Angels, they must save the world from a hell of their own creation... before their water breaks!"
If you thought Volume One was nuts... you ain't seen nothin' yet.
Standard issue when you enlist in the Kickstarter-exclusive edition:
the 24-page main story by the team that brought you RED XMAS
a back-up Frieda tale by Clay Adams, John Edingfield II and Ryan Kroboth 
plus exclusive bonuses
 THE 007 HOMAGE VARIANT
We're keeping our rewards pretty simple this go 'round. But in addition to our epic wraparound cover by Fabio & Ilaria, we have this variant by ALBERT EINSTEIN: TIME MASON's Tony Donley and FIREFLY's Fabiana Mascolo:
"The Man with the Golden Gun" homage by Tony Donley and Fabiana Mascolo.
See below for more on our rewards. But first we dare you to enter...
THE BRIEFING ROOM !
Possible Spoilers! Here's what you need to know -- last issue, The Exalted Father was warned of a dire prophecy:
While his arch-frenemy Thomas Edison--dressed in drag, natch--heard the curious tale of an albino alligator with an... interesting diet. 
OK this double-page spread is really small here... but all you need to know is the name on the book.
Later, Thomas Edison and his crew met up with PBOWs on a bridge high above the body of water where Gustave is said to hunt his prey. It... didn't go well:
And now... 
The Rewards
In addition to our standard and variant covers, there are a few rewards we'd like to highlight. Starting with...
The "Virgin" Cover
Not a lot of virgins here--they're, uh, all pregnant--but you can get Fabio and Ilaria's epic wraparound cover sans writing:
No virgins were harmed making this variant.
And if you're feeling flush, we also have the original art available:
The Sketchbook
Snag a signed sketchbook of Fabio's art for $75, or for $100, he'll personalize it with a sketch of your choice. 
Blank sketch cover is $75. But for a few bucks more, he'll draw something on it... like this!

A peek at some of the awesome art inside the sketchbook.
THE WATERCOLOR
Awesome artist and all-around swell guy Kyle Roberts contributed a pin-up to our PBOW Volume One Trade, and he recently created a limited edition, hand-numbered, hand-painted edition of it. We've got a limited supply of these beauties, so act fast, soldier!
Signed and numbered by Kyle Roberts.
The Add-Ons
Don't see the combo you want? Add digital or physical rewards to your order at checkout for the perfect four-color meal.
THE TIERS
THE PACKAGING--AND THE GUARANTEE
War is hell. So is the USPS. We've received our fair share of comics that got mangled by the mail carrier.
You pay premium prices on Kickstarter, and you deserve better. That's why your supplies will be delivered in Gemini Comic Mailers:
These babies are sturdy. They require a little more money, a little more time (and a lot more tape!) but it's worth it to make sure your comics arrive in pristine condition.
And if somehow your comic still shows up looking like it went through a war zone?
Frieda will replace it free of charge.
Your base of operations will be the FRIED Diner. To many civilians, the diner appears to be a cover for a comics publisher of questionable taste. But don't be fooled by their nine successful Kickstarters--the comics business is ALSO a cover. These people are battle-hardened warriors, and they'll be your guides as you enter the fray.
Clay is the co-writer of RED XMAS from Scout Comics, and he served as co-editor for the NIGHTMARE THEATER anthology on Kickstarter. His feature script, THE ECLIPSE, placed second in the horror category of the FADEIn Awards, and his latest comic, ELECTRIC YOUTH, co-written with Kyle Roberts, was recently featured in the LA Times. He has written and directed for television and holds a BFA in Dramatic Writing from NYU. In a past life, he voiced lead roles on TEENAGE MUTANT NINJA TURTLES, POKEMON, and YU-GI-OH.
Film nerd/director Alexandre is the co-writer of RED XMAS from Scout Comics. His most recent documentary is LEAP OF FAITH: WILLIAM FRIEDKIN ON THE EXORCIST, now streaming on Shudder. He holds a Masters Degree in Dramatic Writing from NYU’s Tisch School of the Arts and has written and directed numerous award-winning films and documentaries, including MEMORY: THE ORIGINS OF ALIEN, 78/52: HITCHCOCK'S SHOWER SCENE, AND THE PEOPLE vs. GEORGE LUCAS. 
Hot off RED XMAS by Scout Comics, Fabio jumps into the PBOW fray from Rome, Italy, where he has published with Sergio Bonelli Editore, Star Comics, Midian Comics and Cairo Editore. Aside from Fried Comics, he has contributed art for a bunch of Kickstarter comics and also some sketch cards for Dynamite Entertainment. Our resident Italian Stallion likes alt rock and (we assume) makes a great cappuccino, but all indications are that he ain't that Fabio.
Ilaria Chiocca is an italian comic artist, illustrator and colorist. She has published two manga style comic books with Shockdom as co-author; she's created many covers and she has been published by Lo Scarabeo publisher as a digital painter, and now she's working as a colorist for Fried Comics, Scout Comics, and many other projects worldwide.
John is a cartoonist, illustrator and writer. He has successfully funded two books of his creator owned series Rancidville on Kickstarter, as well as contributing to a number of anthology projects. He currently skulks in the hills of the commonwealth of Pennsylvania with his family.
Ryan is a writer, artist, and alum of the The Comics Experience School. He successfully Kickstarted his debut comic, SUNMAKER, and contributed art to the ComixTribe column 'The Proving Grounds.'  He loves Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, ninjas, teens, mutants and turtles.
The worst.
Why Kickstarter?
Because wars--like comics--have to be funded, dammit!
Did you know Forbes magazine recently named Kickstarter one of the biggest (and most successful) comics publishers of 2018? We love the direct market and always will, but some of the best comics being produced right now are coming out on this very platform, and we love being a part of this indie, gonzo spirit. Plus, Kickstarter backers are the best. This is our direct pipeline to you, the readers.
*Cough* I mean, soldiers.
OK. Where do the funds go?
copyright Can Stock Photo / pressmaster
Glad you asked. First we will drive around town in our low-rider, windows down and music blaring as we wave it at everyone we see.  
After that, all funds go 100% towards fighting the war: paying the art and design team, printing the books, and shipping them to you. Anything above and beyond that will go towards the next battle, PBOW: WORLD WAR BITCH #3.
Your Tour of Duty:
The Kickstarter Campaign: ~20 Days (May 18-June 17)
Kickstarter Funds Released: ~June 30
Digital Rewards Released: ~August 1
Book Goes to Printer: ~August 15
Book Printed and shipped to us - ~September 1
"$#it happens" buffer - 2 weeks (~September 15)
Pack and ship - (September 15-September 30)
Expected delivery to US backers - 2 Weeks (Late September)
Expected delivery for International Backers - 4 Weeks (Early October)
BEFORE WE GO...
We here at the FRIED Diner are a cowardly and superstitious lot. We read somewhere that Kickstarter pages with a picture of a cat on them do better than others, so here's a picture of Frieda's cat:
THANKS!
Thanks for visiting the crazy world of PBOW. Check out the rewards and pledge with confidence. Together let's Break Kickstarter and give birth to a bitchin' book!
And remember...

Risks and challenges
Any Kickstarter comes with risk, but know this: we have a track record of finishing what we start. This is our 10th project on Kickstarter--all have been funded and fulfilled on time. The book is well into production already, and we're confident we'll make our schedule.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
Standard Cover by Reinaldo Lay

    Retro Variant Cover by Ed Bickford


Confidence Volume One is a 30 page full color comic that follows loveable charlatan Allen on his adventures aboard the luxury star cruiser Iridescence. Allen is a man of many talents, but he excels at knowing what people want or need, and knowing how to get it - mostly through lying and flattery. Using his (questionable)skills, Allen takes advantage of the desires of the passengers and crew of the Iridescence to an unknown end. The story focuses on Allen as schmoozes and tricks people into getting the things he needs from them. All the while, his internal monologue is running through his process and keeping him from getting too bored. He meets a variety of colorful characters in his exploits, ranging from lowly crew members to wealthy passengers. He'll need all of his wit and charm to get what he needs, so that he can get what he actually wants. 
The real question is – what does Allen want?

Confidence Volume One is the second release from Singularity Studios Publishing and is my first solo effort. I am using Kickstarter to fund the costs of the artwork and the printing. As of the launch of this campaign, the artwork is about a third of the way completed. I hope to have the final comic ready to print by mid-June and then on to backers sometime in August of 2021.

Confidence was actually the first comic script I ever wrote back in 2016. It started out as a ten page short that I had my buddy David Wilson draw so that we could submit it to an anthology. Though it didn't get selected for the anthology, it stayed on my mind for awhile after that. I always intended to go back and try to turn it into something longer or ongoing, but life and such got in the way. Once the Pandemic forced us into isolation last year, I had time to flesh out some of my ideas. I worked on Confidence Volume One on and off for about three months before I really found the voice I was looking for so I could tell the story the way I wanted to.  I love the characters I have created and I can't wait to expand their world in future volumes. I had so much fun creating this comic and I want to share that joy with every reader that I possibly can. 

Confidence represents a wonderful collaboration of talent from all over the world and all of us are excited for you to see what we have created.

Todd Zverloff 
Writer/Creator
Todd is a writer born and bred in Akron, Ohio. He has previously written stories for Along a Burning River, a comic anthology of stories about Ohio, a collection he also curated and edited. This is his first full length comic.
Todd can be found on Instagram - @singularitystudioscomics

Rei Lay
Pencils/Inks
Architect and a huge lover of sports and nature. From 2012 has been working in the comic industry, which has been his passion since he was a child.
He has worked drawing comics from Chile to the world, mostly for indie editorials in the United States and Uk, participating in amazing projects  with Alterna comics, Disposable Fictions, Anfibia Editorial and Mobby´s media, among others.

Erick Lay
Colors
Graphic designer, illustrator and a big fan of video games and music. since 2019 he has been working in the world of comics. His works are mainly from the United States, giving color to indies comics and collaborations with different animation projects and
illustrations in Chile.

Cristian Docolomansky
Letters/Logo Design
Cristian was born in Barcelona, 1977, though he now lives in Santiago, Chile. He currently works as an inker or letterer for several American, New Zealand, Spanish and UK publishers, including Heavy Metal Magazine, Scout Comics, Advent Comics, Mythopoeia, Blue Roo Comics, Crow Hill Comics, Arcano IV and Ariete Producciones among others. He is also a comic book teacher for kids and the sole creator for his series In.jvsticia, published now on Ariete Producciones.
Cristian's social media links:  Twitter @docinks  Instagram: @docinks (inks & art) Instagram @docletterscomics (letters).

Ed Bickford

Ed Bickford is an artist based out of Kansas City. He went to school at University of Central Missouri and has a Bachelor of fine arts in commercial art with an emphasis in illustration. In addition to creating Robot Pulp, he created and illustrated the comics The Birdlander, The Troubleshooters, and American Chop Suey. He has also provided illustrations for Planet X Games, Frog God Games, Infinite Worlds Magazine, The World of Myth Magazine, and Image Comics.

Editor
Chuck Pineau is well known in the indie circuit having produced comics as a writer and editor for companies such as Markosia, Antarctic Press, and Scout Comics. He is best known for (co)creating such titles as Belial, Welcome to the Void, and Essence House.

Thanks to your generosity, we have funded Confidence Volume One! It's been a crazy ride, but we made it. Right now my brain is a whirlwind of excitement, relief, joy, and exhaustion. For right now, I'm going to take a few day break and relax. Then it's back to work. I will send out surveys next week, so if you ordered a t-shirt, that will be where you specify which shirt and size you want. 
Thank you all again for investing in creativity and art and believing in this project enough to give your hard earned money to it. You're awesome.

updates.update_userinfo: FUNDED! Confidence Volume One is coming your way!
updates.update_content:
Late last night, we got our 139th backer and it put us over the $4k mark. I'm so excited that we hit our goal and that Confidence will see the light of day. I spoke with Rei last night and he is all ready to jump back on the art and finish the book. I'll give more details once the campaign is over. I just wanted to check in with everyone and share the good news and celebrate a bit. 

While we have funded, I have two friends that need could use a boost as their campaigns wrap up.

Hello all. Things started to come to life this week and we're in good shape heading into the weekend. We passed 100 backers earlier in the week and we are currently sitting at 80% funded. We just need a little more support to get us over the threshold, so feel free to share this out to anyone you know who might be interested so we can all share in the joy of a funded project. 

In the mean time, here are some other indie creators trying to get their books funded as well. These look like some awesome books!

updates.update_userinfo: Closing in on 50% funded and 100 backers
updates.update_content: We're just a little more than halfway through the campaign and we are closing in on 50% funded and 100 backers. Thank you again to everyone who has supported this campaign so far. It means the world to me. I'm not going to lie, though, we still have a long way to go. I'm pushing as hard as I can to get the word out there and to make sure that everyone who will listen sees this project. I want to make sure you and many others get to read this comic as soon as possible. Spread the word if you can. I appreciate any additional support.

updates.update_content:
Greetings! First off, I just want to say thank you for believing in this project enough to pledge your hard earned money toward it. It means more to me than you could know. We are currently sitting at 25% funded here on Day 7. We've had a good start, but we still have a ways to go.

campaign.story:
NIX COMICS: OUT OF TIME
Hello everyone! I'm Ken and I run Nix Comics in Columbus, Ohio.  I could use your help bringing some of the art and writing I completed in 2020  to print in 2021.
Like a lot of people, I had a strange, uncomfortable 2020.  I felt stuck in a strange limbo where I was constantly working, writing, drawing, and creating BUT not publishing.  Last year I managed to put out a few copies a zine titled "What Have I Done For You Lately?" shortly before the pandemic forced isolation.  I've done so much since and I hope that you'll help me self-publish the work with this Kickstarter.

Here's what I'd like your help publishing in 2021:
Out of Time Zines: Two follow ups to the "Lately" zine where I embrace the suspended quality of time instead of fight against it.   Originally, I was going to make just one issue, but I found I had too much good stuff for a single floppy zine... So I've divided the work into two separate zines: Out of Time #1 (storybook) and Out of Time #1 (sketchbook).
 Out of Time #1 (Storybook) is a collection of my fantasy writing through the 2020 isolation, including:
3 Fantasy Short stories
3 chapters of my illustrated novel WIP "On Tour With Roy Lee Hood"
Four preview pages of my comic memoir about my first brick & mortar comic store "Rudy Goose"
a reflection on my obsession with creating a punk rock music and comic arts festival named RATCAF
plans for my next big anthology which I hope will include an LP record titled "The Vicar: Live at the New Rose."
48 Pages B&W plus color cover.
 Out of Time #1: Sketchbook: A collection of drawings from 2020 from my sketchbook. Subjects range from the mundane (stuff like hamburgers, horses and bunnies) to the absurd and, of course, to fan art of musicians, horror movies and comic books.  These were all done in various styles/experimental techniques:
"Eyes Closed:" Drawn quickly (length of one song) without looking at the paper.
"Two Handed: " Drawn with pens in both hands, moving as simultaneously as I can.
"No Lift:" Whole comic pages drawn without lifting the pen, so essentially just one line.
56 Pages B&W plus color cover.
 ICARP 2020 Report: As readers of the SOLRAD literary magazine know, I spent a lot of time in 2020 conducting research and writing essays about the comic arts community.  I call this work my Independent Comic Arts Research Project or ICARP for short. (Sorry, no cute fishy logo. I tried and failed to come up with one I liked) The goal of this research is to provide artists, activists, advocates, academics, and other non-alliterative but otherwise concerned community members some tools for problem framing, problem solving and solution implementation for the issues facing the comic arts community.  I have compiled all of this material into a single report for 2020, which will be available as a PDF for free. Knowing a lot of people, myself included, prefer such things in printed and bound format, I am offering the material here in such a format as a Kickstarter reward.
FREE PDF version available here: 
https://drive.google.com/file/d/1dSieACWOKQMKrcyRApcy6Bl6vdm9C09-/view?usp=sharing
Includes:
A survey of vendors at the 2020 Indie Comics fair in Columbus, Ohio
A survey of 240 Comic Artists conducted on-line
A survey of 49 non-artist Comic Arts community members including fans, non-fans, Journalists, and other Comic Arts professionals
A survey of 30 comic artists about their experiences vending at comic shows, conventions, and festivals
An overview of Comic arts nonprofit organizations as of 2018.
A proposed method for establishing living wage page rates for Comic Artists
120 pages B&W Paperback Book
 Abstracts In Isolation: 
For the first few months of isolation, I began each day creating at least one 7"x7" abstract digital painting in photoshop. The idea was to create images reflective of not only how I was feeling but also how I wanted to feel.  I am going to create a limited number of print sets of 100 of these pieces which will include a set of grid and concentric circle transparency overlays that you can use to make flipping through the prints an interactive experience.  Just wanna look? No problem. Lo-res set of the total collection available here:
https://drive.google.com/file/d/1p7ZiHquZIWWU3pujUzPx7fykcQQ-5HU9/view?usp=sharing
Set of 50 Digital prints with 5 viewing transparencies.
PICK A PIC SLEEVE: Sketch book Picture Sleeves Vol 2 (WIP):
I have continued my ongoing project of making 7" picture sleeves for records.   (The idea is to turn fairly modest sleeveless 45s into a little something special for either/both record and comic art collectors.)  Take a look at the available picture sleeves at the link below! If you want one of these record and original art combos, select the $30 reward and shoot me a message letting know which one you want!  
Available Picture Sleeves Catalog: 
https://drive.google.com/file/d/1YahLKPT1C-FX1NYi_S4XhBfDuFazVWTa/view?usp=sharing
PLAY


REWARDS: 
Print Rewards List
 Print Books and Zines: 
Please note that all print books and zine rewards include shipping in the U.S.  There is an upcharge for shipping outside the U.S.
Out of Time: For $10 you can get a print copy of either the Out of Time Storybook or Sketchbook zine.  (I'll ask you which you want after the kickstarter has ended). For $15 you can get both!
I.C.A.R.P.: For $25 you can get a print copy of the ICARP 2020 research and essays paperback book.  (Please note, that this material is available for free in PDF form.)
ALL THREE: For $40 you can receive all three printed zines and books.
 Sketchbook PS Plus Zines:  For $30 you can receive an original sketchbook picture Sleeve with record plus the two new Out of Time Zines.  Please Note:  This reward takes a little back and forth between you and me.  I don't have enough space to list each original piece of art as an individual reward. Please take a look at all of the sleeves I have available at this link and message me with the sleeve you want when you select the reward.  They will be available first come, first served so maybe have a back up-option or two. I will update the available list every night.
ABSTRACTS IN ISOLATION Print Set: For $60 you can receive a set of 50 prints of abstract art pieces created during the first 100 days of Covid Isolation in 2020. (Images created digitally) Prints on card stock with 5 transparencies for viewing. 
THE WHOLE MAGILLA: For $90 you will receive all three books and zines plus the Abstracts in Isolation print set. 
THE WHOLE MAGILLA (PLUS LEFTOVERS): New to Nix Comics? Or just have some big holes in your collection?  For $150 I will send you all of the new publications and fill out your Nix Comics Collection to the best of my ability. (There's a checklist of all titles to date below, but please note some of them are or are close to being out of print. Absolutely Out of Print items are asterisked)
GET A PICTURE IN THE MAIL FOR HELPING ME GET THE WORD OUT!
 If you share the link to this Kickstarter on Facebook and/or Twitter I'll do an "Eyes Closed Drawing" with a subject of your choice on a 3x5 Index card as a thank you!  AND... If you give me your snail-mail address I'll mail it out to you!  Here's how it will work:
Share the link on facebook or twitter.
Be sure to tag me! (facebook.com/nixcomics or twitter.com/nixcomics)
Give me a prompt. (Tell me what you want me to draw!)
Send me your snail mail address in a DM or email me at ken@nixcomics.com

Thanks again to everybody who backed this kickstarter. It's also so humbling to have my particular brand of weirdness supported by a community of friends, fans, and family.  If you pledged for a reward, you should have a survey in your inbox from me asking for specifics about delivery. PLEASE fill out the survey! updates.update_userinfo: Backerkit Hangups | All Surveys Sent | Instagram Live?
updates.update_content:
First off-- if you are tired of getting these updates in your email inbox, you're not alone. Personally? I read the subject line and then delete campaign updates for projects I back. You can set your account to NOT send you updates about projects in email, make a filter in your inbox to filter out update emails to the trash automatically, or just delete it as it comes in. I put all this time into all these updates specifically because I know some people DO want them. It's easier for me to make it and offer it to everyone, with some people opting out on their end, than it is to find a way to get updates only to people who want them. Also Kickstarter doesn't have a feature for me to do that haha.

Backerkit surveys went out a couple days ago.

Hello! 

It's about time, am I right?
So as of a few minutes ago, I sent out 1,000 surveys. It was a random bundle of 1,000 people, called a 'smoke test'. Basically testing out that everything works. I'm going to give it a few hours, check to see if there are any issues with my surveys, the questions, the items, the shipping, etc. 3 hours from now, so long as it all looks good, I will release a batch of 5,000 surveys (2pm MST). Then I'll wait an hour or two, shoot another 5,000 (4pm MST). Wait another hour or two, shoot another 5,000 (6pm MST). Then after another two hours, I will launch the remaining 3,000~ (8pm MST).

campaign.story:
Kia Wordsmith lives in city where Magic and Science work in harmony, a city that has known peace for centuries. 
A city now at war. 
Bored by the city's attempts to carry on as normal, whilst its soldiers and mages wage war, Kia searches for excitement, and even welcomes a little danger.
In the Kickstarter funded first issue (Kia Wordsmith Issue 1) we saw how this leads to her stealing from a wizard. She then escapes the wizard's tower by following the strange little creature into a different realm. Issue 2 then picks up with the day that follows, where Kia tries to carry on as normal. 
We are currently approaching the £3,000 Stretch Goal. If we reach £3,500 then all physical backers will also receive a free comic celebrating the wonderful artwork of Marleen Lowe who we lost to cancer in 2020. We want you to enjoy seeing what a talent she was.
Between Issues 1 and 2 however Kia journeys through the The Inbetween. A Nexus where all realms interconnect. A place where time and space behave differently. A place where, if you're not careful, you can see glimpses of your life; past, present and future.  
Many seek out the Nexus for power, many more avoid if for fear of what they might see. Kia, of course, is unaware of any of this.
Kia and her new friend are confronted by beings trapped in The Inbetween, and the creature has been altered by its natural habitat.
Kia Wordsmith - The Inbetween consists of a 24 page story illustrated by regular Kia Wordsmith artist Ian Ashcroft and also the original Jigsaw Girl 8 page story by Marleen Lowe, referenced in Ian's pages. 
Jigsaw Girl page from Marleen Lowe
'The Pencils of The Inbetween' is a 20 page sketchbook showing some of Ian's penciled pages from this issue. This will be available in certain reward tiers, along with signed and sketched options.
And if you'd like to own a page of the original artwork then the Magsman tier will let you get your hands on this near A3 piece.
 or this one




Footpad Sample sketch.
Our first stretch goal will be if we should reach £1000, and is the first published art from Ian's 10 year old daughter Eva.
 GOAL UNLOCKED
Should we reach £1500 then all physical backers will also receive a copy of this convention sketch by Dylan Teague.
 GOAL UNLOCKED
 Should we reach £2000 then all physical backers will also receive a copy of this sample from The Pencils of the The Inbetween Sketchbook. It's in Black and White as we'd like to see you're colouring efforts. The best digitally coloured and the best old-school (that's pencils etc) submissions will receive an A4 sketch of a character of your choice from Ian.
Should we reach £2500 then all physical backers will also receive a copy of this art card featuring the art of Andy Meanock. Andy does some great cartoons and caricatures. You can find his work on Facebook.
I love seeing our characters in the style of different artists.
As we are nearing the £2500 Stretch Target I've commissioned an image Tom Brown, who currently has his Hopeless, Maine Kickstarter running, for the £3,000 Stretch Goal.
Tom's work has an Arthur Rackham feel to it which I love. 
Should we reach £3000 then all physical backers will also receive a copy of this art card.

updates.update_content:
Just a quick update to let you all know that our designer, Andy Bloor, has now finished helping pull together the V2A comic and is now able to focus on Kia Wordsmith.
It's important to us that our comics are as professional looking as we can make them and Andy certainly helps in this regard.
The art pages have been complete and lettered for a while now but Andy brings together the other elements to help the inside covers and back cover look good enough to wrap around Ian's glorious artwork.

I've thought long and hard about the Stretch Goal for £3,500 and have decided that if we do hit that amount then all physical backers will receive a free AccentUK comic.
The Inbetween is dedicated to artist Marleen Lowe, who sadly passed away in 2020, aged only 41. 
Marleen illustrated the first Jigsaw Girl story, and her work on this influenced Ian's work in The Inbetween.

We are approaching the £2,500 Stretch Goal so I've commissioned the artwork for £3,000.
This time the artwork is from Tom Brown who illustrates the fabulous Hopeless, Maine.

We are approaching our £2,000 Stretch Goal, so I've been trying to keep ahead of things and have commissioned a couple of art cards.
I love seeing how different artist illustrate our characters and the first of the two is by Andy Meanock, who does some great caricatures and cartoons (you can find them on Facebook). Andy's art card will be the Stretch Goal for £2,500 should we reach it.

campaign.story:
"THE ROAD meets THE CALL OF CTHULHU"
ABYSSAL ALBION the CTHULHU MYTHOS inspired ELDRITCH SURVIVAL HORROR comic series is back with issue 2!
Set after the rise of the GREAT OLD ONES and the fall of humanity. ABYSSAL ALBION takes place in a GREAT BRITAIN where both cosmic and folk terrors are a commonplace and chilling truth.  
Ravaged by death and madness, the series follows the continuing journey of two siblings, SISTER and BROTHER, as they try to survive a world teeming with savage cults and sanity shattering beasts.
 If you are a fan of nightmarish post-apocalypses, doom-laden horror,  and mind bending cosmic dread, this is the series for you! Where our first issue dove head-first into the nightmare filled depths of the British woodlands, the second takes us to its now less than idyllic coastlines.
Though it’s not only overly aggressive seagulls, and the unpredictable British weather our pair will have to contend with.  In their search for Sisters estranged partner the pair face the horrifying and  grotesque -  DEEP ONES.
Half-man, half-fish hybrid,  worshippers of the colossal ancient deity DAGON, Deep Ones now inhabit and control the worlds coastal towns and ports.
Continuing on from our previous 28 Page issue, we shall continue to deliver a unique look at a very weird apocalypse, stunningly drawn in B&W.  
With your support we are set to deliver another quality issue, delving even further into the unknown world of ABYSSAL ALBION.
Written by cosmic horror aficionado, screenwriter, and creative producer for the DEADBOLT Films, THOMAS J CAMPBELL (BEYOND, AND NOTHING HURT) and with artwork by accomplished artist WAYNE LOWDEN (PLAINER JANE, NOCTURNE), lettering by KEN REYNOLDS (COGNITION, HERE AND THERE) and cover colours by TRILBY BLACK.
ABYSSAL ALBION is filled with exciting and spine-chilling homages to the CTHULHU MYTHOS and hopes to continue the tradition of the originators of weird fiction, H.P Lovecraft, Ambrose Bierce, Robert W. Chambers, Charlotte Gilman Perkins, Arthur Machen, amongst others.
Drawn in striking and suitably atmospheric Black and White by WAYNE LOWDEN, with art that perfectly captures the strange and chaotic world our protagonists now find themselves in.
The book itself will be printed on 120gsm uncoated paper to give the pages a slightly rough, more visceral texture, and will feature a 200gsm full colour gloss laminate cover.


BIG COMIC PAGE
"Imagine if you will a story that is similar to The Walking Dead, but instead of zombies shambling across the pages, you have the creeping, insidious horrors spawned by Cthulhu and the rest of his star-spawned family. Okay, I’m not saying that this is another Walking Dead, but it definitely has a similar vibe, and the same potential to be an epic saga given half a chance."
3 MILLION YEARS
"This is a real page turner, with some excellent scenes, art, lettering and storytelling. Hopefully, there is more to come from this world – those with little knowledge of the Lovecraft mythos will enjoy this as much as those who have more."
COMIC BOOK NEWS UK 
"Wayne Lowden  really delivers something special here. It’s art that oozes with unsettling qualities, encapsulating the darkness literally and metaphorically. I like it, I like it a lot. There’s a tangible menace that leaked off the pages for me. Panel after panel delivers incredible detail and emotional weight. It’s a heavy sketch style of monochrome brilliance, rich in shading that just sets a wonderfully dark atmosphere."
THE CONVENTION COLLECTIVE 
"As can be expected, a story in the horror genre deserves some parental discretion. There is cursing and some violence as well as some scary imagery that skews this title towards older readers."
 MIDLIFEGAMERGEEK.COM 
"The intriguing events of the issue set us up nicely to learn more about the siblings and their surroundings as we continue to follow their struggle for survival. With the first issue having come to life with the aid of a successful crowdfunding campaign, I shall be keeping a very keen eye out for the second issue’s launch on Kickstarter."
 Of course you'll need supplies if you're to survive in the harsh world of ABYSSAL ALBION - so by backing us here is just some of what you can get!

Original Art Prints

 As we hit our target and issue two becomes a reality, we'll be releasing a bunch of stretch goals. 
First of which being a unique A4 Mythos Inspired art print commissioned specially for ABYSSAL ALBION from the fantastic Davey Jebadiah Sewell - A master of occult and gothic horror imagery, a couple examples of his beautiful work can be seen below below.
Should we go beyond even further then we have an art  variant by Canadian horror artist and illustrator Trevor Henderson.
Known most famously for his unsettling “SIRENHEAD” creature,  as well as a myriad of other terrifyingly creepy cryptids and weird imagery. As anyone who is aware of Trevor's incredible work will attest, expect something truly uncanny and horrifying.
Keeping with the tradition of a unique campaign video that gives a glimpse into the setting wider ABYSSAL ALBION setting via short film,  SOLITUDE was shot alone during lockdown to serve as further worldbuilding into the world of ABYSSAL ALBION.

$100,000 Stretch Goal: Backers Receive Additional Free GhosTiny Set On Eligible Pledges!!!!!!! 
                                GhosTiny 
 - Ultra Fine Detail Paintbrush Set For Miniatures- 
Ultra Fine Detail Paint Brush Set
In 2019, we set out to create the most affordable set of paint brushes perfect for miniature painters! In 2020, together we released dry brushes that helped new and advanced painters take their gaming miniatures to the next level! The combined 4,644 BACKERS most frequently asked question is "Do you make smaller sizes?" Well, NOW I DO. If you're ready to join the army of painters, hobbyists, gamers, crafters, terrain builders and artists you found the campaign you were looking for.
GhosTiny Ultra Fine Detail Paint Brush Set is the answer to the question "will you make a size #000?" Instead of a single new brush added to the mega popular Ghost Brush line I wanted to create a set that will be your go to when you need to conquer the smallest of details packed into the wonderful miniatures and models we paint today! You probably already know the feeling of using wonderful new paint brushes but I invite you to join the #GhostBrush community and crush your hobby painting goals!
 "Art is never finished, only abandoned."  Leonardo da Vinci

My name is Jeff Beyer. We met the last two years when 4,644 Backers gave me their trust and support in helping bring the Ghost Miniature Paintbrushes to life! With online sales, retail shops, and the last two Kickstarter campaigns, thousands of people are painting with these brushes! You can find me on Youtube under the name RedBeardBoss and on Instagram @Sleepwalkair_brush and I love painting. These past years we showed the bigger companies we wanted quality miniature painting supplies at a fair price. I'm not interested in charging you to cover the bill so I can hire big name studio painters in an attempt to convince you these brushes will bring you 1st place golden trophies. I could send every hobby channel on Youtube a free set and pay them to tell you how great these are but I'm not going to do that either. All you have to do is read the comments from the last TWO campaigns and feel proud knowing you are helping build a community of painters and hobbyists who simply love putting paint on little plastic figures.
Precision
With your support, we will help thousands of new artists fall in love with miniature painting.
Thank you for taking the time to check out my Kickstarter and happy painting!
I would like to introduce you to the GhosTiny Ultra Fine Detail Miniature Paint Brush Set.

This new set of 9 ultra fine detail brushes includes 7 rounds, a flat, and a chisel shaped brush. These not only cover you for the smallest of miniature details but imagine the confidence in being able to choose the perfect shape and size for the task! This set is made with the same beloved white nylon hair of the other Ghost Paint Brushes. The birch wood handles of the new GhosTiny range are thicker and more comfortable to hold when you're focused on getting those tiny highlights in those hard to reach spaces.
Accuracy
Ultra Fine Point
Don't forget the original Ghost Brush Set
Original 8 round Ghost Brushes and 2 Ghost Dry Brushes
If you need a set or two of the original Ghost Brushes I have included pledges just for you! I set out to design the Ghost Brush specifically to help people paint miniatures and people love them! The wide range of sizes were chosen to give you the flexibility to paint the tiniest buckle on your favorite character’s shoe to the massive wings of a terrifying dragon! The white nylon hair holds a nice point compared to most synthetic brushes and is soft enough to achieve smooth blends. Finally, the birch wood handle gives you the feel of being an artist right in your hand. I want you to improve as a painter by having access to quality brushes that get the job done and don't break the bank!
Let's Make The GHOST Dry Brush Size #0D!

The new Ghost Dry Brush #0D has already been designed, tested, and I can include once we reach $50,000. This goal may sound high but the last campaign was over triple this amount! This brush is small but packs quite a punch! It has has a thinner handle than the #1D and #2D in this range and is exactly what you asked for. A smaller Ghost Dry Brush! Don't forget the retail pledges also receive stretch goals earned during the campaign!
Care for your Ghost Brush
The Ghost white nylon hair not only looks great but will help you create better painting habits. Always remember to load the brush with paint only about half way to avoid getting paint in your ferrule. Getting paint inside the ferrule is the fastest way to ruin your brush.

Clean your brushes frequently with water and use brush soap after painting to make sure no paint residue is left inside the bristles. The white nylon hair will change color from use but it is good practice when cleaning your brushes to try and get them as clean as possible.
All paint brushes are designed to pull paint and this one is no different; however, as miniature painters, we tend to use a stabbing motion with our brushes to push paint into small details. This push motion causes the tip of your synthetic brushes to curl over time. To reduce this, use a pulling motion with your brushes as much as possible and if you absolutely need to push paint into a small area, make sure you use very gentle pressure.
NEVER leave your Ghost Brush or any paintbrush sitting submerged in water! This will not only destroy your wonderful sharp tip, it will cause the wood handle to swell and ruin your whole brush. Seriously, stop dropping your brushes hair-down inside a water cup. Instead, swish the brush back and forth in the water to remove paint, then wipe on a towel to make sure no paint is left within the bristles.
These tips will help your new favorite paintbrush enjoy a longer life.

campaign.story:
Jamie Roberts is neither a boy or a girl. They're a PIRATE! And recently, Jamie and their two friends, Thomas and Daniel, have...found, an unfinished map. What can they do with this map?
(An image of Jamie Roberts enthusiastically saying, "Go treasure hunting, of course!")
And so begins the winding, magical, epic adventure that is The Legend of Jamie Roberts.

With your help, we want to get the first 4 chapters of this legend into one beautiful, shiny book. (Some say "graphic novels," some say "trade paperback." I say, "beautiful, shiny book.")

But who's "we?"
Ok, it's the royal "we," because it's me - Kelci Crawford, maker of fine comics for nearly 8 years. And I've run KickStarter campaigns nearly every year since I started, so I know what I'm doing.

The Legend of Jamie Roberts is under my small-press company, Fantasyville Productions, LLC. Sounds like a fancy title, like Captain O'Malley. But sadly, I am a one-person operation on a tight budget, which is why I'm on KickStarter to begin with.
(image of Thomas, Jamie's friend, asking "So Why is The Legend of Jamie Roberts so special?")
This is the story I needed when I was a teenager - confused about my gender identity, wanting to sail the seas and go adventuring away from my positively crap-tastic circumstances. I'm making this story for all those out there like teenage-me, sailing the chaotic seas of their own identity, wanting something new and exciting and adventurous!

This story doesn’t JUST feature pirates - there’s magic! Spirits! And Dragons!

But this is online for me to read, isn’t it?
Yes, the first 4 chapters are available to read online.

So why should I back you?
Because...
a) the book has some redrawn artwork that’s not in the free version. 
b) the book will have bonus content the website does not have - things like extra comics, Q&As with the characters, a behind-the-scenes look at how comic pages are made from script to colors, and much more!
c) this KickStarter will have campaign-exclusive rewards as stretch goals are unlocked!
The rewards available are all listed beside this pitch, so scroll through and see what fits your style (and budget).

Some campaign-exclusive rewards include…
Your VERY OWN orb to stash and protect. Make sure this NEVER breaks, or Ranki will escape!
A map of the land of Corith, complete with notes added by Jamie, Thomas, and Daniel.
A custom-signed copy of each book you order.
Also, for another first, there’s a pledge level where you can order copies of this book for your local library! Libraries have helped us all this past year, and being a former librarian myself, I want to pay that love forward. People deserve books, even if they never knew this KickStarter existed.
Here's a chart with the breakdown for the costs of the campaign:
(A chart showing 40% of costs of the campaign going to printing, 16% of costs going to KickStarter fees, 23% going to ISBN and barcode for the book, 5% for shipping the books to the creator, and 15% shipping to backers)
If you still have questions, check out the Risks and Challenges section below. Hopefully there your concerns will be addressed. But if you still have questions for me, just send me a message.

Can you back this campaign? GREAT! Please do, and share this campaign far and wide! I don’t have Facebook or Twitter (for my own reasons).

Are you broke? Share this campaign far and wide! Each share helps more than you know.
STRETCH GOALS!
(if 5 people download the free coloring book page at http://tinyurl.com/jamie-dragon, color it, and use hashtag thelegendofjamieroberts, I'll add a free bookplate to each book)
**UNLOCKED!** At 15 backers, everyone who pledges for a copy of the book will get The Legend of Norsa, the minicomic, included FREE in their rewards!
**UNLOCKED!** At 20 backers, folks who pledge above $35 will get a FREE sticker sheet of Corith treasures!
**UNLOCKED!** At 30 backers, everyone who pledges for a copy of the book will get the FREE sticker sheet!
**UNLOCKED!** At 40 backers, I'll make a new mini-comic for all backers, The Legend of Azu-Mi!
**UNLOCKED!** At 50 backers, I'll add more bonus content to the book. Specifically: I'll add sketched versions of Chapter 5's first 3 to 4 pages.
At 60 backers, I'll include a sticker of a character from the story in all backer rewards! Vote for who you want to see as a sticker in the Updates section.
More goals coming soon!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
"Wait, weren’t you involved with the KickStarter for NeverEnding? Where’s the rewards for THAT campaign?!"

Yes, I’m still involved with NeverEnding. And yes, we’re still fulfilling rewards for that campaign. But that’s separate from THIS campaign, which is being run under my own company, Fantasyville Productions, LLC. NeverEnding is a separate company, who has a team of artists whom I’m leading to fulfill rewards. Those rewards will get fulfilled as quickly as possible.

With that said, I feel that the rewards for this campaign are distinct enough from NeverEnding’s offerings. I’m comfortable asking you to get The Legend of Jamie Roberts, volume 1 to print because of that.

Also, since this specific campaign is narrower in scope, the rewards can get fulfilled faster. As I’ve mentioned above, I’ve run successful campaigns for the last 8 years on this platform, and all of those previous projects have been fulfilled.



"There’s an option to back this campaign and donate copies of this book to my local library. How are you going to make that happen?"

I’ll admit - this is the first time I’ve made this an option in a campaign. That said, the information I’ll need from you (if you choose this reward option) is the name, address, and/or website of your library. If you have the contact information of the folks who work at your library, that would be even better. If you know who’s in charge of acquiring new books at your library, that’s *chef’s kiss*.

So why am I charging for copies donated to the library? Because printing is expensive. All I’m asking at this reward level is to offset the cost of printing and shipping these books.



“Ok but WHY is the reward donating two copies of a book? Can’t I just give one?”

Speaking as a former librarian, libraries would REALLY rather have duplicates, because books can get lost, damaged, stolen, or otherwise unreturned. If a library only has one copy of a book? That sucks. But multiple copies? Yes, please.



"But Covid-19 is affecting the post office and the delivery of packages in general. "

I know. And to make it even worse, the post office situation in Toledo (where I’m now based) is even wonkier. I’m leaving the window as wide as possible for reward fulfillment to account for these factors.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

Good News! 
The PDF for backers is (pretty much) done! I have an outside reader or two giving it a once-over for spelling and grammar hiccups. I'm getting a little tired of staring at this thing, so I asked for outside help.
Also...The Legend of Jamie Roberts, Volume 1 is now in the Library of Congress system! It's the first book I've made to get the honor. I'm SO EXCITED! Now that the book is in their system, this means that libraries in the United States can access and catalog it for their local branches. This is going to make donating copies (thanks to you backers!) so much easier.

The PDF is NEARLY done, but there's still a few touches left to add.
I wanted to add sketches of Jamie I drew back when I was, like, 14 years old. Because this character has been in my sketchbooks for AGES.
Yet Past-Me thought it was a good idea to get rid of the art made before 2013. So...AUGH. 
There might still be something floating around, but I have lots of other sketches from 2013 and onward. I figure at least ONE old sketch would be cool to have in the book, to see how the art has progressed.

I mentioned this in a post on my blog, but I'll go into more detail here: the PDF for The Legend of Jamie Roberts, volume 1 is running behind schedule. And that's on me.
In the rewards, I had promised that the PDF for the book would be available and sent by the end of May. It's June 2nd now, and the PDF is still being put together.
Why the delays? Well...

The Legend of Azu-Mi, the minicomic, got unlocked when we reached 40 backers.
DON'T WORRY, the minicomic will still happen! It's just...going to be delivered digitally.
I worked on the first round of scripts for it, took one look at it, and went, "There is no way this story will fit in 6 pages or less." Which kind of stinks. The original idea was to make it short, like The Legend of Norsa (another minicomic). That way it would be easy to print multiple copies and send them out.

campaign.story:
"I'm really trying to get out of work, on time."
Connie is a social worker by day. She has clients to see and tedious paperwork to never be caught up on. She also has a special talent and advanced training in removing and preventing demonic possessions in children. That's also during the day.
It's at the same job. Connie Dhar is burnt out and not just because she works in social services. The heat at her day job is only getting worse as incidents become more intense and her personal life goes to hell.

The world has seen a rise in spiritual possessions over the last few decades. In response, the American government has outlawed any possession of minors and created state and federal programs to combat this threat to our safety. C.P.S. (Child Possession Services) is one such program. Constance Dhar is one such disgruntled employee. Connie works for the state division assigned to help bedeviled children remove unwanted spirits and recover. Connie has worked for C.P.S. long enough to have forgotten that she was once a rising star of the agency. Now, she is just going through the motions, between nights at the bar. When a series of truly strange possessions begin popping up, Connie will have to decide if she cares about anything other than the bottom of a bottle and her betta fish. 
Connie at work.
THE BOOK
C.P.S. was co-created by ten-year collaborators- Bobgar Ornelas and Jon Westhoff. Originally part of a series of shorts (published as "Mendicant" and a FCBD anthology with King Bone Press), Bob and Jon are teaming up to bring Connie's first full length story to print. The book will combine the 2 short "origin" stories and a brand-new 26 page tale, with a pin-up by the amazing Bryan Boles, for a 44 page fully colored monstrously over-sized book. This will be the first book from the new publishing company Part-time Comix. This is a one-shot comic, and while there may be lingering questions that we hope will intrigue our readers, this is a complete story. 
Intended for mature audiences: profanity, alcohol usage, adult situations, child endangerment.
Originally created as a one-off story for Bob's series MENDICANT, Connie and all her flaws took a special place in their creators hearts. After another short for FCBD, they set to fleshing out more of her story in her first full sized issue. It has taken some time, but Connie is ready to punch back in and probably punch her boss, if her co-worker can't hold her back. CPS provides a slice of life look at the bureaucratic BS that would happen if American society had an outbreak of demonic possession. Our two short stories provide an intro into Connie and her crew. Our first full length story will go more in-depth into a day in the hellish life of what a social worker for possessed kids. 
Kids amIright??
THE TEAM
Bobgar Ornelas- Co-creator, writer, colors("origin" stories), cover and internal art, Bob is the driving force behind this giant book. Bob has almost 2 decades of indie comic creation and publishing experience. 
Jon Westhoff- Series co-creator, Jon also scripted and letters the 43 pages of Connie's story. He has been creating and publishing comics for over  a decade, with 7 successful crowd funding campaigns.
Winston Gambro- a Chicago based artist and creator of the comedy webtoon Gumshoe City, mystery webcomic, Overflow and the all-ages action comic Rex Radley: Boy Adventurer. During the day he works as a graphic designer and moonlights on comics he hopes you'll enjoy. 
Bryan Boles- Fantastic artist and creator of many of his own characters, Bryan has provided his awesome take on Connie for the book, as a pin-up.
Robert Hafferman- Stunning traditional painter, Robert has provided the Variant full-color cover, for an exclusive tier.
Crows AMIRIGHT??!!
WHY KICKSTARTER?
We are coming back to Kickstarter to help with creation, publishing and printing costs. We have had 7 successful crowd funding campaigns in the past 10 years and are confident in our ability to fulfill backer rewards. Hopefully, an exciting new story and our stellar work history are enough, but there is more info on rewards available below and in the rewards tab.

campaign.story:
Horror fans are always on the hunt for their next great scare. But with so many competing media options available today, fans and creators alike can be separated by platforms, sometimes missing out on great stories. It’s unusual for horror literature and horror comics to overlap, or for either to merge with the horror of the fine arts. Enter - CORRIDOR
CORRIDOR magazine hopes to unite these voices by bringing together creators from all the realms of horror print media. Imagine what it would have been like if Ray Bradbury, Junji Ito, and HR Giger had the opportunity to work together within the same pages! 

The first Oversized 10" x 13" 96-page issue of CORRIDOR will bring together the worlds of short fiction, comics, and fine art. Its stories will blend horror with science-fiction and fantasy, focusing on weird, wondrous curiosities. These horrors will express an uncertainty about reality, invoking a radical strangeness and providing psychological mysteries that dissect our collective fears and anxieties.

Managed by Christian Sager & Dave Moore, Corridor's first issue will feature work from:
Corinna Bechko • Nadia Bulkin • Brandon Daniels • Kristi DeMeester • J.M. Dragunas • Marie Enger •  Ray Fawkes • Ed Grabianowski • Dave Jordan • Jonathan La Mantia • Robert Lamb • Ryan Lee • Brian Level • Maria Nguyen • Dr Eilís Phillips •  Rafer Roberts • Christian Sager • SCARECROWOVEN • Matt Sheean • Kate Sherron • Dave Wachter • Malachi Ward

CORRIDOR also intends to treat its contributors fairly, paying them what they’re worth, with the majority of the budget going to pay them and without taking creative ownership of their work. Our goal is to tell high-quality stories and we hope this creator-centric approach will encourage the best from our diverse group of collaborators.

We recognize these are ambitious goals. That’s why we need your help. Below is a clear breakdown of how your support will finance this magazine. Depending on its level of success, we envision making CORRIDOR available multiple times per year, perhaps even branching out into multimedia storytelling.
Pledge today to get your copy of CORRIDOR magazine’s first issue! By bringing together creators from different worlds of storytelling, you’ll get high-quality, weird tales that blend horror with science-fiction and fantasy. Best of all, this will directly support these creators by paying them fairly and allowing them to retain ownership of their hard work.
CONTRIBUTORS 
A fossil preparator by day and writer by night, Corinna Bechko is a Hugo- and Eisner-nominated New York Times best-selling author who left her heart in the Triassic.
Nadia Bulkin writes stories, thirteen of which appear in her debut collection, She Said Destroy (Word Horde, 2017). Her short stories have been included in editions of The Year's Best Weird Fiction, The Year's Best Horror, and The Year's Best Dark Fantasy & Horror. She has been nominated for the Shirley Jackson Award five times. She has a B.A. in Political Science, an M.A. in International Affairs, and lives in Washington, D.C.
Brandon Daniels is a comic creator and teaching artist living in St. Louis, Missouri. He has worked as a freelance production artist for comic book companies such as Marvel, DC, and Dark Horse Comics. He has written and illustrated self-published comics and contributed to several anthologies. He teaches at several colleges and universities. He is the president and co-founder of STLSPEX, a local non-profit organization dedicated to supporting the St. Louis small press community.
Kristi DeMeester is the author of Beneath, a novel published by Word Horde and Everything That's Underneath, a short fiction collection published by Apex Books. Her writing has been included in  Ellen Datlow's The Best Horror of the Year volumes 9, 11, and 12, Year's Best Weird Fiction volumes 1, 3, and 5, in addition to publications such as The Dark, Black Static, Pseudopod, and several others. Find her online at www.kristidemeester.com.
J.M. Dragunas is a freelance illustrator living near the once frozen lakes of Northern Ohio. 
Marie Enger is a comic creator and illustrator based out of St. Louis. They spend their days working on UNANNOUNCED SPOOKY STUFF x3 and their dark occult western TTRPG CASKET LAND. Past clients include Dark Horse, BOOM!, Oni Press, Image, Netflix, and PUP. Past works include RICK and MORTY, ADVENTURE TIME, ROCKO’S MODERN LIFE, the HEK TREASURY, NOSFERATU! and THE BONES OF THIS PLACE. Their work focuses heavily on identity, the exploration of mental illness, cosmic indifference, and punk bullshit.
Ray Fawkes is the critically-acclaimed author of the comics and graphic novels Underwinter, Intersect, One Soul, The People Inside, The Spectral Engine, Possessions, and Junction True, as well as Batman: Eternal, Constantine, Justice League Dark, and Gotham by Midnight (DC), Wolverines (Marvel), Black Hammer '45 (Dark Horse), Jackpot! (AfterShock) and more. He is an Eisner, Harvey, and Shuster award nominee and a YALSA award winner.
Ed Grabianowski is an author and freelance writer from Buffalo, NY. He’s worked as a contributing writer for io9 and HowStuffWorks, and is a writer and researcher for the Stuff You Should Know podcast. His fiction has appeared in Black Static, David Wellington’s Fear Project, Scourge of the Seas of Time and Space, and other anthologies. Ed has also written non-fiction essays for Apex Magazine and Clarkesworld.  In his other lives, he's driven a race car, designed monsters for fantasy role-playing game publishers, and is the singer in a band called Spacelord. Ed has long been fascinated with the intrusion of the unreal or unimaginable into the lives of previously ordinary people.
Dave Jordan is an artist and writer that lives in Albuquerque with his girlfriend and their fat cat and dumb dog.  He's self-published several comics including Valk, Valley of Ashes, Mitts, and Sadman, has contributed to a couple anthologies including Everything is Going Wrong and King Bone Presents, and has achieved some notoriety for hand drawing metal style logos for mostly non-metal entities and drawing corpses.  He likes records.
Jonathan La Mantia enjoys drawing weird things. He’s been at it for a while and with any luck he’ll be at it for a while longer. 
Robert Lamb is known for his work on the podcasts Stuff to Blow Your Mind and Invention, as well as science writings for such publications as HowStuffWorks.com and Atlas Obscura. He maintains a music blog at SemutaMusic.com. 
Ryan Lee is a Michigan-based Comic Artist/Illustrator. His work specializes in the macabre, strange, fantastical, quirky, and monstrous. Most recently, he was the artist/co-creator of the recent thriller/horror comic, Mountainhead from IDW Publishing. He’s also worked with Black Mask Studios, Marvel, Valiant, and Oni Press, to name a few.
Brian Level is a horror cartoonist, tattooer, writer who has contributed many premiere comic books like Star Wars, Batman, Spider-Man, Avengers and Deadpool to name a few. His work has been internationally well-received for over 15 years. Level brings an element of the horrific and the spiritual to all of his projects with the goal of adding a richness to the work that is able to be revisited multiple times. He lives with his family in the greater Cincinnati area where he makes comics and runs his tattoo shop. 
Maria Nguyen is a Vietnamese-Canadian illustrator whose work has been commissioned for magazines, newspapers, news sites, novels and comics. 
Dr Eilís Phillips is a creative consultant and musician with a PhD in Monster Theory.  Her research centers on the concept of 'monstrous environments'. She has two academic publications due out soon that focus, respectively, on the practice of Spiritualism in WW1 Britain, and on the 'folk horror' aesthetic of Victorian mining reportage. 
Rafer Roberts is the writer and co-creator of Modern Fantasy, published by Dark Horse Comics, and Grumble, published by Eric Powell’s Albatross Funnybooks. Rafer was the writer on A&A: The Adventures of Archer and Armstrong and Harbinger: Renegade for Valiant Comics. His artwork appeared in the Eisner Award winning anthology Little Nemo: Dream Another Dream from Locust Moon Press. Rafer's self-published work includes the recently completed Nightmare the Rat and the Tumblr famous Thanos and Darkseid: Carpool Buddies of Doom which he co-created with Justin Jordan. 
Christian Sager is a storyteller living in Portland, Oregon. He's published several graphic novels and short stories, usually categorized as weird or horrific, including The Cabinet, Valley of Ashes, Canaan Cult Revival and Think of the Children. As a podcaster he's hosted and produced shows like Supercontext, Stuff to Blow Your Mind and BrainStuff. When he's not telling stories he tries to be a friend to both animals and libraries.
From residing in the rural woods of Maine to the urban landscape of New York City, artist SCARECROWOVEN finds solace in his search for bridging polar dualities. On close inspection it should come to no surprise that his hallmark style is comprised of his love for horror, skateboarding, retro video games, animal rights, nature, and both ancient and modern pop culture. His work has been exhibited in galleries across the united states and internationally and his illustrative contributions range from clients like Marvel Comics, Mondo, Creature skateboards, Fright Rags, Warner music, Nike and Horrorhound Magazine. 
Matt Sheean was raised on a steady diet of mythology and science fiction. He never veered from his youthful ambitions to professional illustration and has since published with Dark Horse, Image, and Peow! Studios. His last California-borne solo work was the well-received, absurdist fantasy Fugue. From his new home in the Pacific Northwest, he continues his 15-year collaborative partnership with Malachi Ward (Expanse, Ancestor) while also raising four children with his wife, Danica. 
Kate Sherron is an artist, designer, comic book writer, and Professor of Sequential Art at Savannah College of Art + Design, where she earned her MFA in Illustration many, many years ago. Kate has worked on a number of licensed all-ages properties and is currently developing several creator-owned projects for older readers. She lives and works in Savannah, GA. 
Dave Wachter has worked as a comic book artist on various titles, including Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, Godzilla, Breath of Bones: A Tale of the Golem, and The Guns of Shadow Valley. His current project is a creator owned science fiction war epic called The Detachment. His work has been nominated for both Eisner and Harvey Awards, and he was nominated for the Russ Manning Most Promising Newcomer Award. He resides in Pittsburgh, PA with his family and many cats. 
Malachi Ward is the co-creator of Ancestor with Matt Sheean from Image Comics and Expansion from AdHouse Books. 
 Shipping Collected After The Campaign
Worldwide shipping is available for Corridor, with all shipping fees to be collected after the campaign through BackerKit, to ensure the best possible pricing and delivery options.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
To ensure that Corridor has the best chance at success, we will be utilizing Backerkit after the campaign wraps to facilitate in the project management, and we've enlisted CRWN Studios to help with production and fulfillment. We feel confident that we've given ourselves and our creators enough time to complete their submissions and get the first issue off to print. Barring delays due to world events or factory closures beyond our control, we intend to be fully transparent with our Backers each step along the way!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

The magazines took a little longer on the ghost ship than we anticipated, but they're almost here! We've also successfully gathered all the bundles and art rewards into one location for fulfillment. Get ready!

We're really proud of how it came out!

Production on the first issue of CORRIDOR is well underway, proceeding mostly as we planned. While the contributors have been hard at work on their stories I have been working with our production team of Dave Moore, Mary Connelly and Ron Bilodeau to nail down the printer and get the physical magazine made. We’re reviewing paper samples and finishes, beginning layout and aiming to have the magazine in your hands by May 2021.
Many of the contributors have finished their stories, essays, comics and art, with only a few left in progress. I’m extraordinarily pleased with how everything’s turning out and think you’re going to enjoy this package of weird and wonderful curiosities. A few stand out so well that I’m even considering submitting them for the 2021 awards season!

The Story of Slow Pokes

Written by Steve Urena, Drawn by Juan Romera (IDW, Monkeybrain, Comics Experience) and lettered by Sean Rinehart, (Grief, The V-Card, Dead End Kids) this sloth horror-comedy is a bloody thrill ride you won’t be able to take your eyes off of.
Thanks to Andy Schmidt’s Comic Experience, I was able to make my twisted idea into a reality and I can’t wait to share it with all of you. This has been a dream of mine since I was horribly doodling Spider-Man in second grade and to see this come to fruition is a sight to behold.
Character Sketches
 The comic is completed. I am just waiting on the cover. The digital version will hit the Halloween release date. Due to what's going on in the world, I will provide further updates on the printing situation.
I am using this platform to cover some of my expenses, raise awareness, develop an audience and use the funds towards developing future comic book projects. 
 Slow Pokes Story Synopsis
London James is a rebellious high-school teenager ready to move on to the next phase of his life. The only thing standing in his way is a request from his best friend Karate Carlos…oh and a bio engineered sloth who is now freakishly fast and out for blood. From the twisted mind of Steve Urena, Slow Pokes is a vulgar fun-filled filled horror-comedy thrill ride that’s filled with sloths, slaughter, and slapstick.
 Thank you for checking this out and I hope you have as much fun reading Slow Pokes as I had writing it!

What
I've worked almost every job there is, from Jack in the Box to Portfolio Accounting and Commercial Real Estate, now I want to add business owner to my list. 
After studying business, spending 8 years in construction, portfolio accounting, 5 years of homebrewing, 4 years of collaborating with craft breweries across the US, and visiting breweries around the world, I'm finally going pro. 
Brewing at Guinness
Why
Not only do we want a farm and brewery, but we want to create a space that diversity and inclusivity are not only tolerated but welcomed.  A place where people of color, women, LBTQIA+, and everyone can know that they have a family, a place to hang out, socialize, feel safe, and enjoy good beer.
While there are over 8,000 breweries in the US, there is little representation of people of color. Black brewery owners account for just 1% percent of brewery ownership, according to Bart Watson, chief economist of the Brewers Association. 
Historically, craft beer has been a largely male-dominated industry. However, the number of women working in the field is steadily growing: today, about 29% of brewery employees are female, and about 21% of breweries have at least one woman in a leadership role.
Urban Jungle represents both. There is a brilliance and beauty that comes out of conversation and partnerships and now is the time to begin truly talking and working towards diversity and inclusion. We are hoping that in this moment of crisis, where there's a generation that is pushing aggressively for change, we can be part of the change within this industry and that we own that change collectively. 
Not only do we want to welcome any person from any background, but we want to support their businesses by partnering with them for collaborations and ingredient sourcing. 
This isn’t just about business, it’s about building community.  
Left to Right: James from Forager Brewing, Brandon from Black Beer Travelers, Isla Street Brewing, Will from Equilibrium Brewing, Shannon Harris
Fresh Fest : America's First Black Craft Beer Festival
Where
We plan on opening a farm-inspired brewery within a 45-minute drive from Downtown Austin or the Austin Airport, which makes this area an ideal location for a destination brewery. 
Can't quite picture what we are going for? Some breweries that we would compare our concept to would be:
Jester King - Plan Bee - Hill Farmstead - Blackberry Farm - Vista Brewing
We plan to start construction in Q1 or Q2 of 2021 and aim for completion in Q4 of 2022, although we hope to be done sooner.

Brewed collaborations with Red Horn Brewing, Urban South Brewing, Ingenious Brewing, and J.Wakefield Brewing, as well as participation in the Black is Beautiful initiative.

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Every project has its own risks and challenges. We will mitigate these risks by having a solid business plan.

We are working with an attorney who specialized in TABC and beer laws in Texas as well as Federal licenses and permits.

We rely on mentors who have successful breweries across the country and are working with them to ensure we learn from their experience. 

Use of funds:
- Brewery: to be used for the plan development, design, land survey, well water filtration, and other pre-construction aspects of the brewery.
- Branding & Legal Fees, Permits, and Licences.

The only unforeseen cause for possible delay would be in permitting, weather, or other construction delays. Beer production and releases are dependant on meeting the brewer's expectations. A delay in production is possible if the product is not up to our quality and standards.

campaign.story:
When a technological plague destroys the world, a handful of survivors descend on San Francisco, only to discover that they have only 24 hours before they, too, will be wiped out. Hoping to leave a legacy that will outlast them, they do what any good San Franciscan would; make art out of it.  
Unfortunately, a group of nihilistic programmers have their own deadly agenda and are seeking to expedite the apocalypse. Can the rival factions collaborate on a final act of creation or will humanity’s enduring epitaph be nothing more than sound and fury? 
Ghost Band is a blistering meditation on our self-indulgent tech obsession wrapped in a coming-of-age adventure tale. Silicon Valley meets The Day After. 
From a creative team of California ex-pats comes a biting satire of the tech industry and the cultural decimation it leaves in its wake.
Jason McNamara ( co-creator / writer) is the graphic novel author of Nocturnal Commissions, The Cicada, SUCKER, The Rattler, The Crossing, Abandon, From Mars with Love, The Martian Confederacy, Short Hand, Continuity, First Moon and Less Than Hero. After being squeezed out of San Francisco he landed in Portland, Oregon where he teaches comic book scriptwriting at Pacific Northwest College of the Arts.   
Anke Gladnick (co-creator / illustrator) Anke Gladnick is an illustrator and comics artist who grew up in California and somehow found their way to Portland, Oregon. Through a mix of collaged analog and digital elements, Anke’s work is both visually and conceptually layered with a focus on the surreal and is inspired by dreams, nostalgia and a sense of poignancy. Their client list includes the likes of NBC, Washington Post, NPR and The Intercept. Anke is also part of the successfully Kickstarted comics anthology “No Refunds”, featuring rising talents in sequential art from the Pacific Northwest. 
The goal of this campaign is to fund the creation of an original 96-page graphic novel and to ship it to backers.  We are going to produce and release the work as four digital issues over the next year and then collect the entire story in a printed graphic novel and ship it to backers. This is an ambitious undertaking for us and will require a year of work. 
Previously I have Kickstarted The Rattler, Sucker V1, The Cicada, Sucker V2, and Nocturnal Commissions. I am confident that I can manage this project and create a successful experience for all of our backers. Until the last copy ships, I work for you. 
How many great books will never get made because we destroyed our ability to concentrate through device addiction and the instant gratification of the Internet? How many artists will never make their great works because they are priced out of their communities and homes? Why are we allowing a culture where our metric of value, our own human worth, is based solely on dollars and power?
We explore these themes through Sven and Johanna, a pair of sheltered teens who arrive in the city and immediately find themselves caught between warring ideologies. As they navigate the sensitive politics of the apocalypse, their worlds are broken open; their perceptions of identity, community, and purpose must either evolve or shatter. Torn apart by their differing reactions, the pair must decide: when the world ends, what is left that matters?
